channel.title: Less is better: Why did I wait so long?

item.title: Why did I wait so long?
item.description:
If you have a family, you absolutely must get a telephoto zoom lens. This is what I have:

It’s a Nikon 80-200 f/2.8 lens. It’s pro glass, it’s heavy, but man does it take sharp photos:

Most of the other images that I took on my recent trip were shot using that lens as well. It also works great for candid portrait shots:

The only drawback of this lens is its size. It’s not a lot of fun to lug around. The D200 18-200 f/3.5-f/5.6 kit lens is apparently nearly as sharp:

It has image stabilization and is less than half the weight of mine. But I’m very happy with this lens for the time being, so I doubt I’ll switch.
item.author: jlam@iunknown.com (John Lam)

item.title: "Why did I wait so long?" by John Lam
item.description:
That was the 80-200 zoomed out at 100mm. I also have some earlier shots on my cheapo 50mm prime (see my blog post on rediscovering my 50mm f/1.8). The 50mm prime is equivalent to a 75mm on a film camera and is a very nice portrait lens - providing you can get close enough to the subject. I like having the telephoto zoom because it lets me sit far enough away that, even with the big lens, I can blend back into the background.

Getting the nice bokeh (blurred background) is challenging on DX-sized sensors if you don't have a big aperture. That's what worries me about the D200 kit lens - I'd like to shoot some photos at f/5.6 to see what its bokeh looks, because I really love the subject isolation I can get with it.

item.title: "Why did I wait so long?" by Scott Stout
item.description:
John,

What is the smaller lens you are using. I noticed an older shot (of your bably crawling) on your flikr page that was F2.8 and 100mm. I want to get the nice blurred background in the house. My shots allways have to much distracting stuff in the background when shot insice the house.

Scott

item.title: "Why did I wait so long?" by John Lam
item.description:
I'm using a Nikon D70. I'd wait for the D80 if I were buying now - it should ship in September.

But I'd highly recommend taking a one-day workshop with a local pro photographer. It'll cost you around a hundred bucks and it will improve your skills faster than any equipment will.

The biggest influence on the quality of your photos is what's between your ears, followed by what kind of glass you're shooting with, and lastly what kind of camera body you're shooting with.

item.title: "Why did I wait so long?" by Sam
item.description:
Hi John,

I really like those pictures. I always wanted to get good professional looking shots, but I don't know anything about cameras. I wonder what model of camera you are using aside from that lens that you've shown here.

Sam

item.title: "Why did I wait so long?" by John Lam
item.description:
I'm a family guy, just like you Ted! Hard to justify the 2X price difference for VR ... we're not James Duncan Davidson :)

-John

item.title: "Why did I wait so long?" by http://www.sauria.com/blog
